results.title: Early Melbourne: from village to town
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions, Seven Network Limited (Australia), Lily Steiner and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Dr Bernard Barrett, State Historian, discusses the early development of Melbourne, covering such topics as the naming of Melbourne, who decided where the streets would be located and what they would be called.

results.title: Early marriage
results.brief_description: Deals with teenage marriage, high school counselling and classroom teaching of marriage preparation. Failures are often due to parents and schools making young marriages difficult, rather than ensuring their success. Discusses types of marriage, religious and civil. Symbolism of the ring and post nuptial ceremonies, which should demonstrate the approval and support of parents and friends.

results.title: Early Learning
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
PGR discusses the question: who is the child’s first educator?, and we talk with parents about their role as educators. The role of kindergartens is examined, and we demonstrate how to encourage a love of learning. We look at the importance of language in the learning process, at various aspects of early speech acquisition, and provide tips on the encouragement of a child to develop language skills. PGR also examines the role books and music can play in a child’s early learning development, and we examine the social aspect of developing learning skills.

results.title: Early interactions (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Open University, Michael Philps and Victor Lockwood
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
H.R. Schaffer introduces five experiments which demonstrate the importance of synchronisation between mother and baby. The experiments also show that it is often the baby who initiates the interactions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BBC-TV, Open University, Michael Philps and Victor Lockwood

results.title: Early home consoles
results.brief_description: While the first home console, the Magnavox Odyssey, came out in 1972, it wasn’t the only launched in the decade. Around 1978, the two-player Hanimex TVG-8610C console was released for home use. Featuring detachable joysticks and 10 internally programmed games, it allowed players to customise difficulty levels, automation and keep score. Console like this needed to be run through the home TV to use as a monitor and also required a little domestic diplomacy with family members for a bigger share of screen time.

results.title: Early handling of spinal injuries
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Shows what to do and what not to do in the way of on-the-spot first aid when industrial back injuries occur. Animation illustrates the structure of the spinal column and how paralysis may result from injury to the inner spinal cord. Detailed demonstrations, both in a factory and in a logging camp, show how an accident victim must be handled in order to avoid more serious complications.
